Product Notation in Monoids

For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.
Order of a group
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
Degree of a Polynomial

The degree of a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], denoted by deg f, is defined as the maximum i such that a_i 
eq 0. The degree is assigned -
infty for the zero polynomial.
Ring Epimorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an epimorphism if it is surjective.
Maximal Ideal

A proper ideal $\mathfrak{m} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a maximal ideal if for any ideal $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ that contains $\mathfrak{m}$, $\mathfrak{a}$ must be either $\mathfrak{m}$ or $R$.
Canonical Homomorphism
The canonical homomorphism $\\[Phi: R[X] \\longrightarrow R /(p)[X]\\]$ is a ring homomorphism that reduces the coefficients of a polynomial modulo a prime element $p$ in $R$.
Free A-module

An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.
Degree of a Field Extension

Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension. The vector space dimension $[L: K]:=\operatorname{dim}_{K} L$ is called the degree of $L$ over $K$. The field extension is called finite or infinite, depending on whether $[L: K]$ is finite or infinite.
Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field
The multiplicative group of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group formed by all nonzero elements of $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_q^*\]$. It is cyclic of order $q-1$.
Orbit
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.
Symmetric Group
The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.
Codomain
The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.
